items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Short-Term Hourly, Substitute, Professional Expert & Athletic Support Services, Student Assistant and Volunteer personnel actions as submitted.

items.item_details:
Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as including, but not limited to, detailed records relating to:  records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria fund records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period by an agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
San Jose City College Admission and Records has the following Class III records that meet the three-year criteria for destruction:
	 
Application for Admission
Spring/Sum/Fall 2011
Spring/Sum/Fall 2010   with high school R40s
Spring/Sum/Fall 2009    with high school R40s
Spring 2008
Spring/Sum/Fall 2007
Spring/Sum/Fall 2006 with high school R40s
Spring/Sum/Fall 2005
Spring 2004
Fall 2000
Summer 1999
Summer 1996
Summer/Fall 1994
Spring 1991
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the destruction of records as listed per section 7080.302 of the Retention and Destruction of Records under Board Policies.

items.item_details: The purpose of this grant is to sustain and strengthen certified nursing and home health aide training programs at California Community Colleges.  Grants are awarded to programs providing quality entry level healthcare training for students, thereby creating economic opportunity for individuals, as well as increasing the availability of CNAs and HHAs in California communities demonstrating a critical need in the workforce.  This grant will be used for instructional support, student support, equipment/supplies, and certification fees. Dr. Antoinette Herrera presented a summary of the RFP for the grant to EVC College Council on February 2, 2016.  We received the award letter on April 8, 2016 for $50,000 for the period of July 1, 2016 through June 30, 2017.  No matching funds are required.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept the Dorothy D. Rupe Nursing Assistant Grant funds in the amount of $50,000 for Evergreen Valley College from the Arthur N. Rupe Foundation.
items.item_text: Acceptance of Grant Funds - Dorothy D. Rupe Nursing Assistant Grant - Evergreen Valley College
items.item_text_raw: 8. Acceptance of Grant Funds - Dorothy D. Rupe Nursing Assistant Grant - Evergreen Valley College

items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees is requested to approve out of country travel for students, Anthony Briggs, Braequiana Higgins and Derrick Newton for a study abroad trip to Ghana. This trip is in partnership with Merritt College’s African American Studies Department. The students will be accompanied by Merritt College faculty member Nehanda Imara.  The students will leave San Francisco on Sunday, May 29, 2016 and will be returning on Saturday, June 11, 2016. The estimated cost for travel is $10,200 ($3,400 per person).   
	 
The purpose of this trip is to provide an opportunity to travel abroad to those who might not otherwise have such an opportunity.  This includes economically disadvantaged students, students of color, and students who are single parents in the San Jose Evergreen Community College District.  The primary objective is to globalize their understanding of a third world country historically, culturally, geographically, and economically. Prior to the trip, students will receive numerous lectures on world history, global economics and geography.  While on the study abroad tour students will receive numerous lectures and field study projects from University faculty. Students will also be required to register for 3-units of college coursework at Merritt College (i.e. AFRAM 3-Ghana: Pan African Thought and the Struggle for Africa’s Liberation) during the summer of 2016.  Evergreen Valley College’s AFFIRM Program has partnered with Merritt College’s African American Studies Department for the past three years on study abroad tours.  Evergreen will continue to use Merritt College’s study abroad model to develop its own study abroad program for future students.  No college funds are used.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve out of country travel for EVC students Anthony Briggs, Braequiana Higgins and Derrick Newton.

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1. To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2. To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
